  <strong style="display: block;">A researcher argues that firm-specific events (lawsuits, scandals, product recalls) increase cost of equity because they increase volatility. According to CAPM, what is the correct counterargument?</strong>
<label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q76" value="A"> A. Firm-specific risk is diversifiable and should not affect expected return.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q76" value="B"> B. Firm-specific events always reduce cost of capital.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q76" value="C"> C. CAPM ignores systematic risk completely.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q76" value="D"> D. Volatility and systematic risk are identical concepts.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q76" value="E"> E. CAPM assigns lower return to higher volatility stocks.</label><br>
</form>
